ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Upfield is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This Program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process equipment at the facility.
Upfield senior management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Upfield's safety and environmental policies as they relate to the ammonia refrigeration systems are administered by the Plant EHS Manager, who oversees implementation of the risk prevention policies.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
Upfield is located at 27080 W. 159th Street, in New Century, Kansas. The facility employs two independent refrigeration systems that contain anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant within a closed System; the Conventional system has a maximum inventory of approximately 28,650 pounds of anhydrous ammonia and the Super-critical Melt Micronization (ScMM) system, installed in 2014 with a facility expansion, has a maximum inventory of approximately 32,820 pounds. The systems consisting of vessels, piping, valves, and process equipment cycle ammonia through various states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the manufacturing and storage of margarine. Most of the ammonia equipment is located indoors. The condensing towers, make-up air units, and some piping runs are located outdoors and on the roof of the plant. The relief systems for each of the refrigeration units are also located on the roof.

The Conventional ammonia refrigeration system is a two-stage system consisting of a high pressure side and a low pressure side. The margari

ne processing units (MPUs) operate on the low side (i.e., low pressure) to quickly freeze product on swept surface heat exchangers. Ammonia suction from the MPUs, at about 0 psig, passes through the low accumulator before entering the booster compressors. Any liquid ammonia in the low side suction is trapped in the low side accumulators and returned as high pressure liquid for the system. The booster discharge passes through an intercooler before entering the high side compressors. The high side compressor draws suction from the intercooler/high side suction accumulator at about 25 psig (booster discharge). This accumulator receives suction from various cooler units. Excess ammonia liquid that collects in the high side accumulator is removed and returned to the system. The major discharge from the high side compressors (hot gas) is vented to seven condensing towers. A portion of the hot gas is also used for defrosting and for transferring liquid. A condensed liquid is returned to the high pressure receiver where it is fed to the low and high side equipment, including the MPUs, cooler units, and air handlers. The liquid is pre-cooled in the intercooler vessel before entering the cooler units and a portion of the MPUs.

The ScMM ammonia refrigeration system consists of seven (7) screw compressors that supply high side pressure to the system. The compressed ammonia vapor enters a de-superheater where some heat from the vapor is used to heat production water from 104°F to 140°F. The vapor flows to the evaporative condensers on the roof and is condensed into a high pressure liquid (HPL). The HPL travels to the thermosyphon and the high pressure receiver where the liquid is routed to plate & frame oil coolers integrated with the compressors. The HPL then flows to three surge tanks.  Surge tanks 1 and 2 are used to supply the coolant for the ice water chillers, cooling water to 33°F. Surge tank 3 supplies refrigerant to two plate & frame heat exchangers which are designed

to cool production water to 43°F. The coolant returns to the surge tanks in vapor phase and becomes the suction for the compressors. Ancillary equipment for this system includes three oil pots that accompany each surge tank. There are also water-cooled oil coolers that use the heat from the compressor oil to heat production water.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Upfield ammonia refrigeration systems have many safety features. Much of the safety of the systems is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the systems. For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP). The facility conducts maintenance and any necessary repairs in house, but an outside contractor is contracted as needed.

The Conventional ammonia refrigeration system was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations at the time of construction as well as ANSI/IIAR-1-1984 and IIAR Bulletin Nos. 109, 110, and 111. The ScMM system was designed and constructed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR2 and ASME codes as applicable. In addition, both systems were designed in accordance with the American Society of Heating, Refrigeration, and Air-Conditioning Engineers, Inc. (ASHRAE) standards applicable at the time of construction. ASHRAE publishes a safety code for mechanical refrigeration that outlines requirements for occupancy classification, refrigeration systems classification, refrigerant classification, requirements for refrigerant use, design and construction of equipment systems, pressure limiting devices, pressure relief protection, installation requirements, and field pressure testing.

The ammonia refrigeration systems are protected by the existence of specific safety systems/hardware, including safety relief valves, engine room ventilation, and system safety interlocks. Safety relief valves pro

tect the compressor discharge, condensers, transfer vessels, suction accumulators, intercooler, and pump-out system from the hazards associated with overpressure. Safety interlocks include high pressure and high temperature alarms and cutouts for the compressors, as well as high level floats and sensors for vessels. In addition, ammonia sensors are located in the Conventional system in Engine Room 1, Engine Room 2, Engine Room 3, Ingredient Cooler, De-palletizing area, and King Units; and in the North Engine Room for the ScMM system. At an ammonia concentration of 50 ppm, the ammonia sensors in Engine Rooms 1, 2, and 3 will activate the audible/visual alarms and trigger exhaust fans to start on high mode; this activation occurs at 25 ppm in the ScMM system At 100 ppm for either system, the offsite monitoring company is notified who then contacts all employees and/or agencies listed on the emergency contact list. There are also 2% monitors located in each engine room that will automatically shut down the compressor motors at an ammonia concentration of 20,000 ppm. There is also an Emergency Stop button with a hammer/break glass cover located outside of Engine Room 1 (south of the building) and outside the North Engine Room that, when actuated, kills the control circuit to the compressors, which shuts down the system on auxiliary. The Emergency Stop button also closes the King Valve and triggers exhaust fans to start on high mode. The facility also has exhaust fans which are located in each of the Engine Rooms to provide continuous ventilation and emergency (purge) ventilation. There is an on/off switch for the Engine Room ventilation fans located outside of Engine Room 1 (south of building) for the Conventional system and outside the North Engine Room for the ScMM system. The ammonia detector alarms are interlocked to start the same exhaust fans on high speed. In addition, the facility has developed a preventative maintenance program to complete regularly s

cheduled inspections and tests of the ammonia refrigeration systems as well as repairs as needed to process equipment.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facility has an Emergency Response Plan in effect. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:
1. Save lives;
2. Minimize and avoid injuries;
3. Protect the environment; and
4. Minimize property damage.
The Upfield facility maintains a safety committee whose members include the designated Emergency Coordinator for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to incorporate the facility expansion.
Upfield has a designated Emergency Action Team, whose members comprise of designated personnel, which consists of supervisors and co-workers from the maintenance, production, and distribution departments, and whose purpose is to provide emergency response actions (firefighting, spill control, etc.) in an attempt to further ensure employee safety and preserve company property. The Emergency Action Team members are trained as First Responders and authorized for immediate spill response, meaning a spill or release which can be safely controlled or contained in the immediate area using available personal protective equipment and spill response material/equipment. Spills that are beyond the immediate control of the Emergency Action Team will be dealt with by an external resource. The Emergency Coordinator / Designee will call 9-1-1 and/or other external response agencies as provided on the facility's Emergency Contact Numbers form. In the case of an emergency, the EHS Manager/Designee decides when an evacuation is necessary and the location of the evacuation assembly area to ensure the safety of its employees and

will coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis. The facility holds evacuation drills at least once per year.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The EPA's RMP Program defines accident as the following:
The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following:
-On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (68.42(a)); or
-Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (68.42a)).
A review of the facility's accident history determined that there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in the last five years (2018 - 2022). In addition, there have been no releases of ammonia that meet the RMP definition of accident as described above.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The most recent Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) updates for the Conventional and ScMM systems were conducted on Septembeer 23rd, 2022. The PHA studies included a HAZOP analysis. The PHA Revalidation provided recommendations to improve safety at the Upfield facility located at 27080 W. 159th Street, in New Century, Kansas.

The Upfield safety committee is committed to continual efforts to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  Ongoing activities include the following: 
1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.
2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.
3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.
4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
